Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on a boulder, showing the pecked, infilled figure of an antelope (gerenuk?), probably gazelle and an unidentified shape. The antelope is upright and facing left, on the right hand side of the boulder, with a long neck and small head. The unidentified shape is across a crumbling rift in the rock, in the form of an undulating pecked line. A 5 cm photo scale has been fitted at the base of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: This engraving site is on the ancient riverbank. Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
